Award.AwardTitle: Multilevel methods in PDE constrained optimization
Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this project is to develop efficient multilevel
algorithms for large-scale optimization problems constrained by partial
differential equations (PDEs) with additional inequality constraints (ICs)
on the controls and states. The computational revolution of the last two
decades has fostered not only high-resolution numerical computations based
on PDE models, but also a shift from model based simulation to model based
design. The latter translates into the question of solving optimization
problems in order to identify initial and/or boundary values, material
properties, sources, and other parameters for which the PDE models behave
in a desired way. However, in general, by increasing resolution not only
do optimization problems get larger, but they also become more difficult
to solve, thus rendering an ever widening gap between the resolution of
PDEs and that of associated parameter identification problems that can be
solved using state of the art resources; in order to take full advantage
of these resources, highly efficient algorithms are critical. While such
efficient algorithms have been developed over the past few years, they are
mostly restricted to problems without ICs. The addition of ICs on the
controls and/or states normally increases the difficulty of the problem
due to the presence of Lagrange multipliers that have lower regularity
than the solution. Recent years have witnessed a sensible progress in the
optimization algorithms that target such problems, however, it is expected
that significant efficiency can further be gained by improvements in the
linear algebra technology needed during the optimization process. In this
project the PI specifically aims to develop optimal order multilevel
preconditioners for the linear systems arising in the interior point
method and semismooth Newton method solution processes of optimization
problems constrained by linear and semilinear elliptic or parabolic PDEs
with ICs on the controls and/or states. For the more difficult problem of
state ICs, both Lavrentiev and Moreau-Yosida regularizations will be
considered. The long term goal is to develop efficient multilevel
algorithms for large-scale control problems for fluid flows (Stokes, and
Navier-Stokes systems).

The results of this project are expected to enable end users of the software
- engineers, applied scientists - to solve
high-resolution, relevant optimization problems at a cost that is
comparable (a small multiple of) to that of performing a single
simulation. Long-term targeted applications include data assimilation for
weather prediction and air contamination modeling. Fast data assimilation
for high resolution models would enable, for example, gaining in a timely
manner a better quantitative understanding of the current state of the
atmosphere around a hurricane, thus potentially improving the current
predictive capabilities. From an educational perspective, the successful
project will help the PI's efforts in promoting this field of research at
University of Maryland Baltimore County (UMBC), and it will allow graduate and undergraduate UMBC students to gain
experience in a research area of strategic interest, which is likely to
increase their opportunities of finding a good position in a research
university or laboratory.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Computer simulations of physical phenomena are often based on the numerical solution of partial differential equations (PDEs). The widespread availability and decreasing price of computational resources over the last twenty-five years has fostered a multidimensional computational revolution, with engineers and scientists attempting to simulate increasingly complex phenomena in their quest to understand and predict the behavior of various systems, natural or manufactured. At the forefront of computational science await problems that involve a wide range of scales in space and time, and that require high-resolution simulations; such simulations are continuously pushing the boundaries of our computational capacity. Accurate weather prediction, climate modeling, nuclear reactions are examples of such problems.  It is widely accepted by the computational science community that novel algorithmic approaches are as essential as hardware development for tackling the most challenging problems. The work in this project was focused on developing efficient algorithms for a class of problems known as PDE-constrained optimization problems (PDECONs).

 

Problems formulated as PDECONs take PDE models one step further: while simulations based on PDE models attempt to predict the behavior of a given system based on a fixed set of known parameters (initial state, material properties, etc), PDECONs attempt to use PDE models to identify sets of parameters for which the system behaves in a desired way. For example, the question of determining the state of the atmosphere at a moment in the past – called here the initial state - given a number of temperature, pressure, humidity, and wind measurements over a certain interval of time and at a number of locations, can be formulated as a PDECON. The main challenge of solving a PDECON of this kind lies in the potentially very large size of the problem: setting goals of identifying millions or even billions of unknown parameters are not unusual.  Current techniques, however, do not allow for solving PDECONs at the same extreme resolutions at which the PDE models themselves can be simulated, at least not for PDEs of practical interest such as weather models. This project attempted to break this line of thought by developing a special class of algorithms based on multigrid ideas, to show that, in fact, PDECONs can, in principle, be solved efficiently even at resolutions that are comparable to the largest resolutions at which PDE models can be simulated.

 

The project was focused on a number of problems where the PDEs model stationary temperature profiles (linear and semilinear elliptic equations), stationary fluid flows (Stokes and Navier-Stokes systems), and problems where the parameters to be determined are constrained to a given interval (control-constrained problems). The project succeeded in showing that multigrid methods specially designed for the problems enumerated above can be very efficient for solving large-scale PDECONs, thus paving the way for the possibility of solving extreme-scale PDECONs of practical interest. The project resulted in a number of scientific publications in high-quality journals, and in a Ph.D dissertation and a B.Sc. thesis. The PI and students have also presented their results at numerous scientific conferences.
